channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: French Police Arrest 5 in Terrorism Raid
item.description: The arrests were part of a continuing effort to combat terrorism after the deadly attacks this month in and near Paris that left 17 dead, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Flydubai Jet Hit by Gunfire as It Lands in Baghdad
item.description: The attack, which took place on Monday, added to fears that Iraq’s airports are increasingly vulnerable to militant attacks.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China to Force Authors to Provide Real Names When Publishing Online
item.description: Linking the offline identities of authors with their online writings, new guidelines say, will encourage writers to “better take responsibility” for their works and bolster “moral education and training.”
item.category: State Administration of Press, Publication, Radio, Film and Television (China)
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hao Qun, known to most readers as Murong Xuecun, is one of many prominent Chinese writers to use a pen name.

item.title: Obama Ends Visit With Challenge to India on Climate Change
item.description: President Obama pressed India on Tuesday to do more to curb emissions, as he wrapped up a trip that failed to achieve a meaningful breakthrough on the issue.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: President Obama addressed an audience of 1,500 mostly young Indians at Siri Fort Auditorium in New Delhi on the final day of his trip.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Luigi Tomba on Privatized Housing and Political Legitimacy in China
item.description: Mr. Tomba, a China expert based in Australia, talks about how the privatization of housing in China appears to be strengthening the grip of the Communist Party.
item.dc:creator: By IAN JOHNSON
item.media:description: Luigi Tomba, author of "The Government Next Door: Neighborhood Politics in Urban China."

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Save the New Ukraine
item.description: The pro-European reformers desperately need financial aid to survive Russia’s assault.
item.dc:creator: By BERNARD-HENRI LÉVY and GEORGE SOROS

item.title: Vote Result in Greece Challenges More Than Austerity
item.description: The leftist politician created the government with a right-wing fringe party that will charge immediately into the task of reversing wrenching austerity policies.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Alexis Tsipras paid tribute to victims of a Nazi massacre in Athens on Monday after being sworn in as prime minister of Greece.

item.title: British Inquiry Into Death of Ex-K.G.B. Officer Begins
item.description: Alexander V. Litvinenko was poisoned with a rare radioactive isotope, polonium 210, as he sipped tea in an upscale London hotel in November 2006.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Saudi Succession Hints at Shift in Foreign Role
item.description: Prince Mohammed bin Nayef, the new deputy crown prince, embodies Saudi Arabia’s shift to a more assertive foreign policy, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:credit: Saudi Press Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Saudi Arabia’s new top leadership: King Salman, right, Crown Prince Muqrin, center, and Prince Mohammed bin Nayef, left.

item.title: Obama Leading a High-Powered Delegation to Saudi Arabia
item.description: A bipartisan group of prominent current and former officials will join the president as he offers his condolences on the death of King Abdullah.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: U.S. and India Share Sense of Unease Over China
item.description: President Obama found that his concerns were closely aligned with those of Prime Minister Narendra Modi, and the two leaders agreed to a joint statement chiding Beijing.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: President Obama with Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India, third from left, during the Republic Day parade in New Delhi on Monday.

item.title: World Briefing: WikiLeaks Assails Google and the U.S.
item.description: Lawyers acting for WikiLeaks said Monday that they were exploring possible legal action against the American government and Google over the seizure of emails.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: World Briefing: Italy: Prosecutors Seek Long Sentence for Cruise Ship Captain
item.description: Prosecutors on Monday asked a court to convict the captain of the Costa Concordia cruise ship and sentence him to 26 years in prison for the 2012 shipwreck off Tuscany that killed 32 people.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Canada: Residents Tests Positive for H7N9 Bird Flu After Trip to China
item.description: A resident of British Columbia has tested positive for the H7N9 avian flu virus in the first documented case of the infection in a human in North America, the federal government said Monday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Libya: Kidnappers Free Government Minister
item.description: The deputy foreign minister of Libya’s internationally recognized government was released Monday after being kidnapped a day earlier, said a security official.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: A Nigerian City, Long Under Siege, Survives an Audacious Militant Assault
item.description: In some ways, it seemed as though the city of Maiduguri had returned to normal just 24 hours after a fierce Boko Haram attack.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Argentine Leader Attacks Spy Agency Amid Furor Over Prosecutor’s Death
item.description: Argentina’s president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, accused rogue factions of trying to sabotage a deal with Iran to investigate a 1994 bombing that the prosecutor, Alberto Nisman, was looking into.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO and JONATHAN GILBERT
item.media:description: Damián Pachter, the first to report the death of Alberto Nisman, fled to Israel.

item.title: World Briefing: Israel: Dissident Reservists Dismissed
item.description: The military on Monday terminated the service of 43 reservists who in September signed a letter refusing to participate in “actions against Palestinians” for moral reasons.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Open Source: Killing of Protester Prompts Rare Criticism From Egyptian State Newspaper
item.description: The death of the protester, whose body was riddled with shotgun pellets, was condemned in an unusually frank editorial on the front page of Al Ahram.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: U.S. Drone Kills 3 Qaeda Operatives in Yemen, Continuing Policy on Strikes
item.description: The drone strike was a signal that the United States will continue its targeted killing operations in Yemen despite the apparent takeover in the country by Houthi fighters.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER and MONA EL-NAGGAR
